div.p:
Some interesting correspondence has passed between Baron
Humboldt and the Mexican Government. In a letter from
Lucas Alaman, Secretary of State for the Mexican Republic,
his Excellency states that the Baron’s luminous writings rela-
tive to America had been received with general satisfaction,
and that the rending of the work had not a little contributed to
vivify the spirit of independence, and to arouse others from
the lethargy in which they were held by foreign domination.
The Government, heartily concurring in the general sentiment,
had directed his Excellency to express their lively hope that he
would carry his intention into effect, of once more returning
to Mexico, so that they might congratulate themselves on
counting amongst the number of the inhabitants of the Re-
public, a man so illustious and justly esteemed throughout
the civilized world. The Baron, in reply, says, “Engaged
in a career dedicated entirely to the cultivation of the sciences,
and to the support of the eternal principles on which the
progress of reason, and the amelioration of public institu-
tions depend, nothing could flatter my self-love more
than this solemn testimony, expressed in so noble and in-
teresting a manner. I therefore beg your Excellency to pre-
sent to your Government this homage of my profound respect,
and of my eternal gratitude. If the works which I have pub-
lished have produced any good, it should be attributed only to
my love for the truth and the purity of my sentiments, and to the
admiration with which I have been inspired by a country whom
nature has destined to so exalted a fate. I am not without hope
of beholding once again (my Sovereign permitting) the majesti
Corderillas of Anahuac; of studying once more their natural
productions; and of enjoying the pleasure of witnessing the
progressive happiness which must necessarily be produced in
the bosom of the Republic by free institutions and the arts
of peace.”

In a subsequent letter, addressed to “General Guadalupe
Victoria, President of the Mexican Republic,” the Baron
writes, ar the request of an aged father and two sisters, to ob-
tain the liberty of Col. Carlos Benesky, with whom he was
not personally acquainted (although he is from the Prussian
colony, and his countryman). He had learned that Benesky,
who had done signal services in the last wars of his country,
had been induced, by an error of political opinion, to follow
the fortunes of @turbide. The wishes of Baron Humboldt
were anticipated, Col. Benesky having been sent out of
the country some time before the letter was received.
